title.narrative: Mashambanzou: Att minska sårbarheten hos barn 2017-19

description.narrative:
Mashambanzou Care Trust syftar att bygga vidare på resultat och erfarenheter från tidigare program som har bedrivits med stöd från ambassaden. Mashambanzous program ämnar förbättra situationen för 1000 barn samt deras familjer i Harare genom aktiviteter inom vård och omsorg som stödjer barn.
Sjukdomar samt fattigdom drabbar barn hårdast. De blir i många fall tvungna att ta ansvar för hushållet, ekonomin och även sjuka familjemedlemmar. Många av de drabbade barnen avslutar därför sin skolutbildning i förtid samt stigmatiseras av samhället. Mashambanzou hoppas att förbättra barnens samt familjers levnadsförhållanden genom att: - komplementera statens utbud av grundläggande social service till barn i behov, såsom tillgång till hälsovård och undervisning - stärka befintliga strukturer i samhället för omsorg och vård av barn som lever i svåra förhållanden - sprida kunskap om barns rättigheter samt vikten av folkbokföring - sammanlänka informella och formella system för barnomsorg - minska näringsbrist bland barn genom utdelning av matpaket samt kunskapsspridning via mödragrupper - integrera psykosocialt stöd i hälsosektorn samt skapa lokala stödgrupper, särskilt för barn som lever med HIV - stärka familjers ekonomi genom utbildningar i hushållsekonomi samt informera om inkomstbringande aktiviteter.
Programmets ambitioner överensstämmer med den svenska strategin för biståndsinsatser. Där framgår att ökad tillgång av grundläggande social service ska främjas, för utsatta grupper med särskilt fokus på barn och unga.

This project seeks to reduce the vulnerability of children in adversities as a result of poverty, HIV, TB and disability by enhancing the extent to which households provide a supportive and stimulating learning environment to children on various aspects of development (physical, social, emotional, language, and cognitive development). The family focused approach where the child is at the centre and the family members form the supporting structures is utilized

This project seeks to reduce the vulnerability of children in adversities as a result of poverty, HIV, TB and disability by enhancing the extent to which households provide a supportive and stimulating learning environment to children on various aspects of development (physical, social, emotional, language, and cognitive development). The family focused approach where the child is at the centre and the family members form the supporting structures is utilized. To reach this aim the project envisaged the following objectives: 1. To provide support to 1000 children (affected by poverty, HIV, TB and disability) and empower them with knowledge and skills to deal effectively with their life obstacles2. To provide holistic health care to 350 parents and guardians of vulnerable children who are critically ill from HIV and TB related conditions so as to improve their quality of life3. Capacity development for staff, families and communities to ensure efficiency and sustainability

tag.narrative: 3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.
4.2 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
4.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar har tillgång till förskola av god kvalitet som ger omvårdnad och förbereder dem för att börja grundskolan.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative: The Mashambanzou, Reducing Vulnerability of Children contribution was implemented between 2017 and 2019. The main objective of the intervention was to address poverty-stricken children whose parents have been infected and affected by HIV/AIDS and orphan hood caused by HIV/AIDS. This was done through provision of support to vulnerable children, enable social services to directly assist vulnerable children and integrate the national HIV/AIDS response by supporting adult persons living with HIV/AIDS who also are caregivers to children. Mashambanzou contribution targeted highly vulnerable and poor members of the community with a focus on Harare`s high density suburbs namely Dzivarasekwa, Glen Norah, Highfields, Hopely, Mabvuku, Mbare and Tafara. These suburbs are characterised high HIV infection compounded by other social and economic vulnerabilities that make accessing health services particularly for their co-infections much more difficult. The contribution focused on children who have been made vulnerable through diseases such as HIV, TB as well as poverty and disability, either by themselves falling ill or a family member. By complementing and improving delivery of basic social services as health care, psychological support when affected by fatal diseases and providing food packages and training on nutrition, the programme contributed to improving the living conditions for these children as well as protect them from harmful exposure. This was achieved through three components, that is, Mashambanzou Day Care Centre, Mashambanzou Care Unit and Houses of Safety that made up the family centred approach. In line with the rights-based approach, the day care centre located in Mbare provided day care services, nutritional support and early childhood learning for almost 200 children (58% of these were girls) aged 4-6 years in the three years the protect children's right to life, good healthcare and education. The day care centre provided a safe space for these children which boosted their psychosocial, cognitive and motor development. The contribution also built linkages with the parents and guardians of the young students to raise awareness and promote children’s rights. The programme also placed 83 children (64% were girls) into the temporary houses of safety who were then reintegrated with family, adopted or placed in permanent children’s homes. In the past three years Mashambanzou Care Unit played a key role in provision of a comprehensive package to the people affected by HIV/AIDS- prevention, care, treatment and support. The care unit reached 908 clients (59% were females) providing a combination of palliative care to the very poor with advanced illness, facilitated access to Anti-Retroviral Treatment (ART) for the poor who could not afford them through normal channels and psychosocial support, spinal support, nutritional support, physiotherapy, all of which enhance the quality of life of people living with HIV. Of those admitted, 16% were referred for further management at other specialised facilities, 48% had positive outcomes and were discharged and 17% died. The families of the clients also received positive prevention training that included training on how to care for the sick, and counselling for disclosure, stigma and discrimination and livelihoods programmes. The broader socio-economic environment resulting in reduction in disposable incomes of clients led to defaulting in treatment, delays in seeking health services and many foregoing routine health checks. As long as the scenario remains like this Mashambanzou services will remain critical and vital in reaching the most vulnerable of the population with much needed clinical and social services.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
